front.note: Published in final edited form as:

docTitle.titlePart:
The air-Q ® intubating laryngeal airway vs the LMA-ProSeal™: a
prospective, randomised trial of airway seal pressure *

byline.docAuthor: R. E. Galgon 1 , K. M. Schroeder 2 , S. Han 3 , A. Andrei 4 , and A. M. Joffe 5

byline.affiliation:
1 Senior Resident, Department of Anesthesiology, University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and
Public Health,

2 Assistant Professor, Department of Anesthesiology, University of Wisconsin School of Medicine
and Public Health,

3 Research Professor, Department of Anesthesiology, University of Wisconsin School of Medicine

4 Assistant Professor, Department of Anesthesiology, University of Wisconsin School of Medicine

5 Assistant Professor, Department of Anesthesiology and Pain Medicine, University of
Washington-Harborview Medical Center,

front.div:
Summary
We performed a prospective, open-label, randomised controlled trial comparing the air-Q ® against
the LMA-ProSeal™ in adults undergoing general anaesthesia. One hundred subjects (American
Society of Anesthesiologists physical status 1–3) presenting for elective, outpatient surgery were
randomly assigned to 52 air-Q ® and 48 ProSeal devices. The primary study endpoint was airway
seal pressure. Oropharyngolaryngeal morbidity was assessed secondarily. Mean (SD) airway seal
pressures for the air-Q ® and ProSeal were 30 (7) cmH 2 O and 30 (6) cmH 2 O, respectively (p =
0.47). Postoperative sore throat was more common with the air-Q ® (46% vs 38%, p = 0.03) as was
pain on swallowing (30% vs 5%, p = 0.01). In conclusion, the air-Q ® performs well as a primary
airway during the maintenance of general anaesthesia with an airway seal pressure similar to that
of the ProSeal, but with a higher incidence of postoperative oropharyngolaryngeal complaints.
NIH-PA Author Manuscript
* Presented in part at the Society for Airway Management's Annual Meeting, Chicago, USA; September 2010.

Competing interests
None of the authors have any financial relationship with any of the device manufacturers with an interest in the subject matter of this
study. Further, none of these manufacturers were involved in the design of study, study conduct, data analysis and / or manuscript
preparation.
